data.name: label9.Text
data.value: Nerve centers located intranevraxial and extranevraxial, in relation to the vegetative organs whose activity controls it, form the vegetative nervous system. Within the vegetative nervous system we distinguish, structurally and functionally, a sympathetic nervous system and a parasympathetic one. Most organs receive a double and antagonistic vegetative innervation. In other organs, the sympathetic and parasympathetic exert effects of the same kind, but these effects are different, quantitative and qualitative. There are also organs on which only one system has an effect. The centers of the sympathetic system are displayed in the lateral horns of the C8, - T12 and L1 - L2 marrow, so in the lower cervical, thoracal and upper lumbar marrow. The centers of the parasympathetic system are located in the parasympathetic nuclei in the brain stem, as well as in the sacral marrow S2 - S4, where the pelvic parasympathetic nucleus is described. Parasympathetic nuclei in the brain stem are: • The autonomic nucleus of the nerve III (oculomotor), located in the mesenchefal. Preganglary parasympathetic fibers from this nucleus enter the third nerve (oculomotor) and then leave it heading toward the ciliary ganglia, where they make synapses with postganglion fibers that reach the sphincter muscle of the pupil and the ciliary muscle. • The lacrimal nucleus in the bridge transmits its preganglary parasympathetic fibers into the VII nerve, which they then leave, heading toward the pterigopalatin ganglion, where they make the synapse with the postganglion fibers that reach the lacrimal gland, nasal mucosa glands, and palatines. • The upper salivary nucleus is located in the bridge, just below the previous one. The preganglary fibers also penetrate into the VII nerve, which they then leave to make the synapse with the postganglion fibers, "into the submandibular ganglia. Postganglion fibers provide secretory innervation of the submandibular and sublingual glands. • The lower salivary nucleus is in the bulb. The preganglary fibers enter the Nerve IX, then leave it, heading toward the Otic ganglia, making the synapse with the postganglion fibers that distribute to the parotid gland. • The dorsal nucleus of the vagina (cardio-pneumo-enteric) is located in the bulb, under the lower salivary nucleus. Preganglary fibers enter the vagus nerve, then 11 leave, making the synapse into various ganglia (cardiac plexus ganglia, pulmonary plexus ganglia and celiac plexus) with postganglion fibers that are distributed to cardiovascular and respiratory devices, esophagus, stomach, small intestine, check, ascending colon and transverse colon. The synapse between the pre- and post-ganglion fibers is done in the cardiac plexus for the cardiovascular system, in the bronchopulmonary plexus for the respiratory system, and in the submucosal and myenteric plexuses for the digestive tract. • The pelvic parasympatic originates in the sacral marrow (S2-S4), from which the preganglional fibers enter the pelvic nerves originate. These fibers make the synapse with postganglion fibers that are distributed to the descending colon, sigmoid and rectum.
